docs.text: rick-roll-detector ¶ rick-roll-detector is a Python module that uses facial recognition to detect Rick Astley in a image, video file, or Youtube video. See the Getting Started guide to start using rick-roll-detector.
docs.title: Home

docs.text: rick-roll-detector is a Python module that uses facial recognition to detect Rick Astley in a image, video file, or Youtube video. See the Getting Started guide to start using rick-roll-detector.
docs.title: rick-roll-detector

docs.text: API ¶ rick-roll-detector ¶ rick_roll_detector.verify_image(image: numpy.array) -> bool ¶ Tells you if a image contains Rick Astley. rick_roll_detector.verify_video(cap: cv2.VideoCapture) -> bool ¶ Tells you if a video file contains Rick Astley. rick_roll_detector.verify_youtube_video(url: str) -> bool ¶ Tells you if a Youtube video contains Rick Astley.
docs.title: API

docs.text: Tells you if a image contains Rick Astley.
docs.title: rick_roll_detector.verify_image(image: numpy.array) -> bool

docs.text: Tells you if a video file contains Rick Astley.
docs.title: rick_roll_detector.verify_video(cap: cv2.VideoCapture) -> bool

docs.text: Tells you if a Youtube video contains Rick Astley.
docs.title: rick_roll_detector.verify_youtube_video(url: str) -> bool

docs.text: Command Line ¶ rick-roll-detector includes an awesome CLI to scan images, video files, and Youtube videos! Usage ¶ To scan a Youtube video in the command line you could do: rick-roll-detector --youtube YOUTUBE_VIDEO_URL Options ¶ -i, --image TEXT Scans an image for a Rick Roll. -v, --video TEXT Scans a video file for a Rick Roll. -y, --youtube TEXT Scans a Youtube video for a Rick Roll. --help Show this message and exit.
docs.title: Command Line

docs.text: rick-roll-detector includes an awesome CLI to scan images, video files, and Youtube videos!
docs.title: Command Line

docs.text: To scan a Youtube video in the command line you could do: rick-roll-detector --youtube YOUTUBE_VIDEO_URL
docs.title: Usage

docs.text: -i, --image TEXT Scans an image for a Rick Roll. -v, --video TEXT Scans a video file for a Rick Roll. -y, --youtube TEXT Scans a Youtube video for a Rick Roll. --help Show this message and exit.
docs.title: Options

docs.text: Getting Started ¶ Install ¶ Installing rick-roll-detector is very simple. Installing with PIP: pip3 install rick-roll-detector Basic Usage ¶ Using rick-roll-detector is very straight forward. To check if a youtube video is a rick roll you can do: from rick_roll_detector import verify_youtube_video print ( verify_youtube_video ( "YOUTUBE_VIDEO_URL" ))
docs.title: Getting Started

docs.text: Installing rick-roll-detector is very simple. Installing with PIP: pip3 install rick-roll-detector
docs.title: Install

docs.text: Using rick-roll-detector is very straight forward. To check if a youtube video is a rick roll you can do: from rick_roll_detector import verify_youtube_video print ( verify_youtube_video ( "YOUTUBE_VIDEO_URL" ))
docs.title: Basic Usage

docs.text: Image ¶ You can scan an image file using the verify_image function. First let's import the necessary packages. import numpy import PIL from rick_roll_detector import verify_image Now let's import your image and turn it into a numpy array. image = PIL . Image . open ( "YOUR_IMAGE_PATH" ) image_array = numpy . array ( image ) Now let's use the verify_image function. if verify_image ( image_array ): print ( "The image is a Rick Roll!" ) else : print ( "The image isn't a Rick Roll." ) Your final product should be: import numpy import PIL from rick_roll_detector import verify_image image = PIL . Image . open ( "YOUR_IMAGE_PATH" ) image_array = numpy . array ( image ) if verify_image ( image_array ): print ( "The image is a Rick Roll!" ) else : print ( "The image isn't a Rick Roll." )
docs.title: Image

docs.text: You can scan an image file using the verify_image function. First let's import the necessary packages. import numpy import PIL from rick_roll_detector import verify_image Now let's import your image and turn it into a numpy array. image = PIL . Image . open ( "YOUR_IMAGE_PATH" ) image_array = numpy . array ( image ) Now let's use the verify_image function. if verify_image ( image_array ): print ( "The image is a Rick Roll!" ) else : print ( "The image isn't a Rick Roll." ) Your final product should be: import numpy import PIL from rick_roll_detector import verify_image image = PIL . Image . open ( "YOUR_IMAGE_PATH" ) image_array = numpy . array ( image ) if verify_image ( image_array ): print ( "The image is a Rick Roll!" ) else : print ( "The image isn't a Rick Roll." )
docs.title: Image

docs.text: Video ¶ You can scan a video file with the verify_video function. First let's import the necessary packages. from rick_roll_detector import verify_video import cv2 Now let's create a VideoCapture of your video file. video = cv2 . VideoCapture ( "YOUR_VIDEO_PATH" ) Lastly, let's use the verify_video function. if verify_video ( video ): print ( "The video is a Rick Roll!" ) else : print ( "The video isn't a Rick Roll." ) Your final product should be: from rick_roll_detector import verify_video import cv2 video = cv2 . VideoCapture ( "YOUR_VIDEO_PATH" ) if verify_video ( video ): print ( "The video is a Rick Roll!" ) else : print ( "The video isn't a Rick Roll." )
docs.title: Video

docs.text: You can scan a video file with the verify_video function. First let's import the necessary packages. from rick_roll_detector import verify_video import cv2 Now let's create a VideoCapture of your video file. video = cv2 . VideoCapture ( "YOUR_VIDEO_PATH" ) Lastly, let's use the verify_video function. if verify_video ( video ): print ( "The video is a Rick Roll!" ) else : print ( "The video isn't a Rick Roll." ) Your final product should be: from rick_roll_detector import verify_video import cv2 video = cv2 . VideoCapture ( "YOUR_VIDEO_PATH" ) if verify_video ( video ): print ( "The video is a Rick Roll!" ) else : print ( "The video isn't a Rick Roll." )
docs.title: Video

docs.text: Youtube ¶ You can scan a Youtube video with the verify_youtube_video function. First let's import the necessary package. from rick_roll_detector import verify_youtube_video Then we should create a video_url variable. video_url = "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQw4w9WgXcQ" Finally, let's use the verify_youtube_video function. if verify_youtube_video ( video_url ): print ( "The video is a Rick Roll!" ) else : print ( "The video isn't a Rick Roll." ) Your final product should be: from rick_roll_detector import verify_youtube_video video_url = "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQw4w9WgXcQ" if verify_youtube_video ( video_url ): print ( "The video is a Rick Roll!" ) else : print ( "The video isn't a Rick Roll." )
docs.title: Youtube

docs.text: You can scan a Youtube video with the verify_youtube_video function. First let's import the necessary package. from rick_roll_detector import verify_youtube_video Then we should create a video_url variable. video_url = "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQw4w9WgXcQ" Finally, let's use the verify_youtube_video function. if verify_youtube_video ( video_url ): print ( "The video is a Rick Roll!" ) else : print ( "The video isn't a Rick Roll." ) Your final product should be: from rick_roll_detector import verify_youtube_video video_url = "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQw4w9WgXcQ" if verify_youtube_video ( video_url ): print ( "The video is a Rick Roll!" ) else : print ( "The video isn't a Rick Roll." )
